fields.description:
For a particular build there will often be several users. If that build 
fails a notification email will be sent out. It however will not 
necessarily include every committer's name in the subject line or body. 
 This causes problems for filtering email for the purposes of identifying 
when you're the source of a build failure.
fields.summary: Enhance email template for failed builds

fields.description:
The builds currently running are not all being displayed at the *Building* section of the *Current Activity* Dashboard.

It is not a javascript problem, since opening http://localhost:8085/build/admin/ajax/getDashboardSummary.action is also failing to provide the Json data for all the builds.

Other parts of Bamboo are able to provide the data even if they come from the same source (ie. the Job page is showing progress without problem).

See screen shots provided at https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-4170
fields.summary: Current Activity not always showing builds in progress

fields.description:
Currently, the Dashboard has Alternative texts for icons (see image_1 attached), however the Current Activity page, doesn't (see image_2).

This is necessary for accessibility reasons. Also, since accessing Bamboo through ssh tunnel does not display the icons, the text option is a real necessity to allow users to see the build results.
fields.summary: Ensure that all Icons have alternative text

fields.description:
Even if the build results were deleted, Bamboo is still making DB calls to check each of them during indexing processes.

This operation will take a few milliseconds per check, but for example, big instances with 30K deleted builds will do "nothing" for 17 minutes.

Currently Bamboo always iterates from 1 to <last-build-number>. Bamboo should iterate only on the existing builds.
fields.summary: Indexing process still try to index deleted builds

fields.description:
Basically what I want to do is allow my users to log into their bamboo site, fire off a plan but be able to pass options to the plan that are specific to the user needs. (Not the set of variables that are already defined within bamboo). So for example, the user launches the Plan passing it some value.. that value ultimately gets used when the build script is called. So if I'm using PERL, it's passed into the PERL script as a parameter and the build acts accordingly.

The idea behind it is that at night when the build runs, it will fully build everything we are working on. During the day, if a developer just wants a certain part of the solution they can pass a parameter stating what they want and the build process will create the correct sub solution.
fields.summary: Set system vairables on one-off builds

fields.summary: Internal server error in BEAC gadget on JAC

fields.description:
I have several build jobs that all share the same build invocation that contains several variables that are build agent capabilities. Whenever this invocation changes, I have to go and edit the many jobs that use it.

What I would like to be able to do is defined the build invocation as a single global variable, that itself uses variables that are capabilities of the build agent. This would allow me to define the invocation in one place which would simplify maintenance.

Another alternative would be to introduce build invocation templates that can be shared among jobs (across different plans). These templates could themselves have variables that could be unique to the job that must be configured there, which would allow the common parts of the invocation to be defined centrally yet still facilitate differences per job.
fields.summary: Allow nested/recursive expansion of variables in build invocation

fields.description:
This issue is raised due to the recent comments in BAM-7928.

The problem is that outdated plugins (for example [git-plugin-1.2.4.jar|https://github.com/downloads/krosenvold/bgit/git-plugin-1.2.4.jar]) might explode when used on upgraded Bamboo instance. In the previous version of Bamboo such plugins would work correctly, but in newer version of Bamboo they throw exceptions here and there. As a result they render some pages non-functional - like the repository configuration page - disallowing users to create new plans or edit existing plans.

Attached screenshot shows and example of an exception that is caused by an outdated/incompatible plugin. This exception stops the edit repository screen from working.

Question is whether we can change some code in Bamboo core to handle exceptions better, such that a bad or outdated repository plugin cannot make the whole screens non-functional?
fields.summary: handle exceptions better, such that a bad or outdated repository plugin cannot make the whole edit-screen non-functional

fields.description:
Hi, today in Tardigrade (3.1-SNAPSHOT build 2403 - 14 Mar 11) I tried to configure an AMI with a different (old) set of Bamboo Ec2 libraries.

The agent didn't start as per the following message:
{code}
org.springframework.jms.UncategorizedJmsException: Uncategorized exception occured during JMS processing; nested exception is javax.jms.JMSException: Failed to build body from bytes. Reason: java.io.InvalidClassException: com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.BuildContextImpl; local class incompatible: stream classdesc serialVersionUID = -7720241326122611533, local class serialVersionUID = -546656420244222661; nested exception is java.io.InvalidClassException: com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.BuildContextImpl; local class incompatible: stream classdesc serialVersionUID = -7720241326122611533, local class serialVersionUID = -546656420244222661
Caused by: javax.jms.JMSException: Failed to build body from bytes. Reason: java.io.InvalidClassException: com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.BuildContextImpl; local class incompatible: stream classdesc serialVersionUID = -7720241326122611533, local class serialVersionUID = -546656420244222661
{code}

Interestingly enough, Bamboo was neither able to shutdown the instance (by pressing the shutdown button) nor to start new ones. So this could show some hidden problem in the EC2 start / shutdown.
fields.summary: Bamboo can't shutdown current EC2 instance or start new ones after launching one with incorrect (old) classes inside

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in Bamboo's User Management pages. This affects Bamboo versions 1.0 to 2.7.3.
* An attacker might take advantage of an XSS vulnerability to steal the current session of a logged-in user.
* XSS vulnerabilities potentially allow an attacker to embed their own JavaScript into a Bamboo page. An attacker's text and script might be displayed to other people viewing the page.

This issue is reported in our security advisory on this page:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/rAP5FQ

We recommend you to upgrade your Bamboo installation.

You can read more about XSS attacks at cgisecurity, CERT and other places on the web:
* http://www.cgisecurity.com/xss-faq.html
* http://www.cert.org/advisories/CA-2000-02.html
fields.summary: XSS in Bamboo User Management

fields.description:
This is from http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+Artifact+Sharing+between+Jobs

{quote}
*To share an artifact between two Maven Jobs in different Stages:* 
# Edit your {{pom.xml}} file and add the following plugin definition: 
{code:xml} 
<build> 
  <plugins> 
    <plugin> 
      <groupId>com.atlassian.bamboo.maven.sharing</groupId> 
      <artifactId>bamboo-artifact-sharing-maven-plugin</artifactId> 
      <version>3.0-i5</version> 
      <executions> 
        <execution> 
          <id>sharing</id> 
          <goals> 
            <goal>share</goal> 
          </goals> 
        </execution> 
      </executions> 
    </plugin> 
  </plugins> 
</build> 
{code} 
#* Note, the version number specified above ({{<version>}}) must match the version of Bamboo you are using. This version number number will be compatible across minor releases of Bamboo, unless specified otherwise in the relevant upgrade. 
{quote}

So I tried to specify 3.0, since that's the version of Bamboo I'm using. That version doesn't exist. I see bamboo-artifact-sharing-maven-plugin version 3.0-i5, bamboo-maven-artifact-sharing-plugin 3.0-i5, and bamboo-maven-artifact-sharing-plugin 3.0-rc1...which of those do I want?
fields.summary: Documentation for Maven Artifact Sharing is unclear
Add more logging for Moving/Copying artifacts in LocalArtifactManager

fields.description:
Bamboo has been working fine with me until now, but I've recently changed my git repo to include a submodule. Bamboo is now stuck at the fetch stage with this error message:

Error occurred while executing the build for BUILDNAME : Checkout to revision 2ae68669f7aa1fd6dc3855168f5a3b35deccb5de has failed.Missing unknown c8d9bfe6ceac1d49f338589bc2978e9a3a1d71dd

2ae68669f7aa1fd6dc3855168f5a3b35deccb5de is the hash for the project and c8d9bfe6ceac1d49f338589bc2978e9a3a1d71dd is the hash for the submodule.

I'm not a expert git user, but I think the fix is fairly easy: the git fetch code is missing a "git submodule init", or "git submodule update".
fields.summary: Bamboo's Git code does not seem to initialize submodules

fields.description: If there is a failure in the build process which cannot be handled by Bamboo, the author of the next build gets accused of spoiling all of the (already) failing test cases. In "pic-01.png" you can see that there were unhandled failures during builds #80 and #81 (they do not appear in the list of performed builds). Now build number #82 goes fine, however there are several test case failures reported. A problem here is that all of them are reported as *new* ones, what can be seen in "pic-02.png". This in turn causes a person running build #82 to be accused of spoiling all of the failing test cases, you can see that in "pic-03.png", despite of the fact that all of them had already failed with build #79. Bamboo should be able to track previous build number correctly. There is absolutely no reason to report these errors as new ones, and it causes unability of tracking the actual first reason of each failure.
fields.summary: Build process failure causes the author of the next build to be accused of spoiling all of the (already) failing test cases

fields.description:
This was seen on BEAC.

When viewing a job in the second stage whilst the first stage is still building (so has not been queued yet).  The plan is manually stopped so the pending job moves into a NOT_BUILT state. However, the build in the first stage is still building (the stop message is taking a while to get through).  The page refreshes like crazy until the build finishes in the first stage.
fields.summary: Job Result Summary page continuously refreshing for pending job.

fields.description:
Important: this is not the functionality that can be achieved with the Custom Capabilities. We don't want to direct a Plan to be run in an agent, but to make some agents unavailable to some plans.

For instance, having Team A and Team B. We want Team A to run its Plans on Agent A only and Team B to run its Plans on Agent B only. Since there are limited resources, if Agent A is used by Team B, this will upset Team A, as it will have to wait B finishing using the resource.
fields.summary: Allow the Admin to restrict certain Agents to be available to certain plans only

fields.description:
I've been trying to create a cross-product way of doing restores through a REST resource.  This would make life much simpler for doing integration tests in that we could put applications into a "known" state before a test is run.  I tried writing a REST resource to do this for Bamboo, but found that I could not get the [ImportExportManager|http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/3.0/com/atlassian/bamboo/migration/ImportExportManager.html] injected.

Any chance of we can make this available to plugins for uses such as this?
fields.summary: Make ImportExportManager available to plugins

fields.description:
The notification schemes (at a build level) are for a plan as a whole and then all the jobs as a whole. 

This feature would make notifications configurable at a Job level. Therefore, notifications can be sent for Jobs 1, 2, and 4 for one subset of people, and then Jobs 3 and 5 for another set.
fields.summary: Configure notifications at a per job level

fields.description:
If Bamboo is restarted when some builds are in the queue (waiting to be assigned to an Agent), when Bamboo is running again, the builds that were queued are set to *Unknown* state ([yellow icon|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Viewing+a+Build+Result]) and canceled. 

See screen shots attached.

The builds should survive a restart and continue queued until an Agent is available.
fields.summary: Build queue should persist across restarts

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo does not stop the builds or wait then to finish in order to start a Scheduled Backup.

This may cause backup inconsistencies since new data is created in the DB while it is being flushed into the backup zip.
fields.summary: Wait all builds to finish before starting a Scheduled Backup

fields.description:
Bamboo does not stop builds in order to start performing an Export.

The Export page needs to be clearer about this and alert the Admin to wait until the builds are finished. Otherwise, new data will be created in the DB during the Export and the export package will be inconsistent.

*Good to have:*
- Show what are the exact builds running
- Show a green sign to the Admin confirming that the builds finished and that he can start the export.

OR

- Always start the Export, but before starting the backup wait the builds to finish.
fields.summary: Let the Admin know that Builds are still running in the Export page

fields.description:
It's important to have control on how stages are trigerred. For example we have a "release" stage that uploads the project and send a notification to the stakeholders, so not every time we build we want to release the project.

Nevertheless when releasing it's not necessary to pack up the software again and run all tests, we could take advantage of artifact promotion and just upload the last war built.

So trigger control would be a huge plus. The same scenario applies for deploy in production, deploy in customer testing environment, etc.

One step foward would be to have fine grained security on stage trigger so that project manager or customer could trigger one stage while a developer couldn't.

These changes would allow to use bamboo as a real continuous delivery tool!
fields.summary: Have control on how stages are triggered

fields.description:
I give all of my devs the Build permission on the QA builds on the projects they work. This means the user can both start a build and stop a build (even if they didn't start it).

Two reasons for this, in my opinion a build stop only needs to be done if it has hung, and this should be left to an admin who can sort out the underlaying issue.

Secondly if someone does hit stop on one of our builds there is a high possibility that the build machine will have to be manually cleaned up. This is due to us having lots of COM and COM Interops being registered as part of the build, the build script always finishes by cleaning these up so builds on other branches won't get conflicts. How I understand Bamboo's stop to work is that it attempts to simply terminate the script, the dirty COM is going to be left for the next build to cry about.

Now at the moment it's a matter of training that no one is going ot do it, but i'd rather avoid someone forgetting or accidently clicking.
fields.summary: Expand Build Permission into 2 permissions to allow users to start but not stop builds.

fields.description: Similar to BAM-8156. We spend 14% of the sample time calling {{com.atlassian.aws.ec2.RemoteEC2InstanceImpl#describeInstance}} for every instance. We should be calling this once with a list of instances we are interested in periodically and caching the result. This involves the removal of the {{backgroundSupervise}}.
fields.summary: Improve EC2 Instance information management

fields.description:
In dogfood 25% of the sample time was taken calling {{RemoteEC2Instance#getAttachedVolumes()}}. For each ec2 instance we call the describeVolumes endpoint at Amazon which returns a list of all the active volumes and filters the result so we only get a list of volumes for the instance we are interested in.

The fix here would be to have a single scheduler job that fetches the volume data and put it in a map somewhere. Callers then get the cached copy of the volumes for a specified instance when {{RemoteEC2Instance#getAttachedVolumes()}} is called.
fields.summary: Improve EC2 Volume Management Performance

fields.description:
We are now checking out the whole source tree as a default for plan but some jobs need only a module of it. Thus it would be really helpful if it was possible to define URL for plan and relative URL for jobs.

Example 1:
||Plan's Repository URL|https://svn/repos/myproject/trunk| |
||Job's Repository URL|build|_This would checkout https://svn/repos/myproject/trunk/build_|

Example 2:
||Plan's Repository URL|https://svn/repos/myproject/trunk/build| |
||Job's Repository URL|../databases|_This would checkout https://svn/repos/myproject/trunk/databases_|

The first example would benefit us the most. This would save us a lot (well, time is relative ;)) of time when creating new plans cloning the existing ones.
fields.summary: Make it possible to use job's Repository URL relative to plan's Repository URL

fields.description:
I have a build process that commits a lot of different files in different locations. The include/exclude file option when set to exclude allows one pattern to be set to exclude revisons from triggering a polling repository build.

However if that revision has files that match the exlusion, and files that don't match the exclusion then the revision does trigger the build. So as it stands the exclusion only works if all files within the revision match the pattern.

If there are multiple files in different locations then a single pattern is not flexible enough. Some files may only sometimes be checked in by the build, some files may be exclusivly checked in by the build process, whereas others could be checked in by the build and by normal users.

What I would like to see is a checkbox option to allow one match to be enough to exclude a trigger.

I could then have the pattern match a single file that I know the build will update, have this checkbox checked, and the revisions would be ignored.


Note I have also created BAM-8122 which looks at a different way of solving my issue but in a different way that may be more suitable for a wider audience.
fields.summary: Option to ignore revision if any files match exclude file expression on Polling Repository Plans

fields.description:
I have a build process that commits a lot of different files in different locations, meaning that the include/exclude file option is not suitable in 3.0 to exclude the build process' checkins. My checkins are done by a dedicated svn user, and the comment is unique and predictable (e.g. 'QA Build x.x.x.x)

I would like to be able to supply an expression that is checked against revision author and/or comment. If it matches then the revision does not trigger the build.
fields.summary: Option to set an ignore pattern by repository comment/author
